text: Akio Toyoda, Chairman of Toyota Motor Corporation (TMC) was recently recognized by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) Foundation with the 2025 Industry Leadership Award, at the 27th Annual SAE Foundation Annual Celebration held in Pontiac, Michigan.   The event recognizes and pays tribute to the career accomplishments and generous spirit of industry professionals who inspire the next generation of innovators. In celebration of this recognition, Toyota Motor North America is providing a gift of $1 million to directly support the SAE‚Äôs A World in Motion (AWIM) program which helps introduce students to STEM education.

This week, Toyota Senior Vice President of Enterprise Strategy & Solutions Christopher Yang was recognized by Ascend as part of their A-List Award Honorees. Please join us in congratulating Chris Yang for his professional achievements and work to support others in the automotive industry and beyond.  Congratulations, Chris Yang!

Devan said, ‚ÄúBeing able to relate to each other in motherhood, hobbies, coffee and career topics has created a strong bond between us and without Toyota we would have never met!‚Äù When asked what stood out about the community at Toyota North Carolina, Shelby said, ‚ÄúThese are the people you are with, day in and day out. When things get challenging, you want to have a support system at work to help navigate that and encourage you through the hard times.‚Äù Devan agreed and added, ‚Äúwhen you have wins, big or small, they stand in your corner and cheer for you and with you!‚Äù Ready to become a valued part of the Toyota North Carolina team? Toyota pays it forward every day, making a positive impact across communities. From mentoring others to supporting sustainability, team members are driving change with purpose.   In Alabama, Justina Thwing is leading the charge in manufacturing by mentoring and supporting the next generation of leaders. Her dedication to encouraging women to explore manufacturing is creating opportunities for women to thrive.   In Kentucky, Ben Kasa is giving children with mobility challenges the freedom to ride through his work with AMBUCS, building adaptive tricycles. Every bike he helps create brings a smile and a sense of independence to a child.   In Indiana, Toyota team members are turning a small space into a pollinator garden, planting 1,250 pollinator plugs to support local biodiversity. This effort is part of Toyota‚Äôs Environmental Challenge 2050, contributing to a sustainable future.   In Texas, the Women in Toyota group is inspiring young girls to explore careers in STEM, partnering with Girls Inc. to show them the possibilities in science, technology, engineering, and math.   Toyota‚Äôs commitment to paying it forward is more than just a statement‚Äîit's a movement making real, lasting change in communities across the country. ü´∂üèª #PayItForward #ToyotaImpact #WomenInSTEM #CommunityEmpowerment #LifeatToyota

‚ÄúVeterans are often faced with complex challenges that require quick thinking and effective solutions, and this problem-solving mindset is directly applicable at Toyota.‚Äù   Toyota is proud to invest in our nation‚Äôs heroes by helping them find work after their valued service. Aaron M. provided 10 years of military service as a Sergeant in the United States Marine Corps, and he‚Äôs now a crucial part of our Quality Control team at Toyota North Carolina. As part of our team, Aaron has seen his military skills directly translate to his daily work, and he says he has been able to ‚Äúleverage the analytical skills honed during service to contribute to process improvements and operational excellence.‚Äù Aaron also mentioned that Toyota has been an excellent fit for him because, ‚ÄúVeterans emphasize certain core values instilled by military service, such as integrity, commitment and a strong work ethic. These values align closely with Toyota‚Äôs culture, which is focused on respect for people and continuous improvement.‚Äù   As a member of the Toyota Veterans Association (TVA), Aaron said, ‚ÄúEngaging with TVA can help veterans navigate their careers at Toyota more effectively and foster a sense of community.‚Äù When asked what advice he would share with veterans looking to join Toyota, he said, ‚ÄúVeterans bring a wealth of unique skills and experiences to the workplace, and it is crucial for veterans to recognize these strengths and communicate them effectively during the hiring process.  Highlighting how military training has prepared them for challenges in a corporate environment can set them apart from other candidates.‚Äù

Brianna is a veteran of the Marine Corps who brings her specialized knowledge to Toyota‚Äôs maintenance team.   ‚ÄúPrior to Toyota, my background was in aviation electronics‚Äîthink Geek Squad for helicopters. The skills I bring‚Äîtroubleshooting, general mechanical skill and understanding‚Äîhave continued to develop at Toyota as I am exposed to new systems. Because of how much they invest in employees, Toyota wants us to be successful and trained in multiple systems. As I became more comfortable in the workings of water treatment, I started to branch out into other facility systems.‚Äù   Speaking to other women who want to join this traditionally male-dominated field, she adds: ‚ÄúI would tell them to be all in. In many other places of employment, being a woman in maintenance might hold more of a stigma, but Toyota embraces it. If you make it, you didn‚Äôt get here by mistake. You did so because you had the knowledge and skillset to pass the test and interview.‚Äù   Click the link below to explore our maintenance roles. https://lnkd.in/d47RMctB

At Toyota Missouri, team members recently embraced the principles of Ji Kotei Kanketsu (JKK) during a unique quality training session. JKK, which means ‚ÄúBuilt in Quality with Ownership,‚Äù focuses on improving work processes through collaboration. Our team members from the production line came together to assemble bicycles without using instruction manuals, learning from their mistakes and each other.  The assembled bikes were donated to Youth In Need, an organization dedicated to building positive futures for vulnerable children, teens, and families in eastern Missouri. We are honored to be named Youth In Need‚Äôs Outstanding Corporate Partner for 2024, a testament to our commitment to giving back to the community.  Thank you to all our team members for their hard work and dedication!  #ToyotaMissouri #JiKoteiKanketsu #CommunityEngagement #LifeatToyota

Toyota Motor Manufacturing Alabama now has a 30-megawatt solar energy system, thanks to a $49 million project with Toyota Tsusho America, Inc. (TAI) and Huntsville Utilities. This project will generate about 70% of the plant‚Äôs total energy usage and support Toyota's goal of carbon neutrality at all North American facilities by 2035.  ‚ÄúToyota is committed to clean and sustainable power. We know that the collective future for our community and our team members depends on clean mobility, clean air, clean water, and biodiversity. We are thankful for our partners on this project who have created a model of environmental stewardship in North Alabama.‚Äù -- Jason Puckett, president of Toyota Motor Manufacturing, Alabama.  Learn more at https://lnkd.in/ec5JQdeV #LifeatToyota

At Toyota, we deeply value our veterans for their sacrifice and dedication, both in service to our country and as integral members of our team. Through initiatives like our Hiring Our Heroes program, our business partnering group - Toyota Veterans Association, and community outreach, we strive to provide meaningful opportunities to veterans after their valued service.  Meet Toyota's truck guy and Army Veteran Sam D.! Sam shares how his military career prepared him for his role at Toyota and the importance of recognizing veterans:  "I look back on my time in the Army as one of the most defining of my life and career. The military experience teaches you to be mission-focused ‚Äì and accomplishing those missions revolve around teams and squads of soldiers. Continuous improvement was at the heart of everything we did, as well. I encourage anyone with prior military experience to seek out an opportunity at Toyota.   Currently, I‚Äôm the co-chair of the Toyota Veterans Association North American Advisory Council (NAAC). It‚Äôs important to highlight and celebrate our amazing team members who committed a part of their career to serving others. I also encourage people to seek out that military veteran in your family or community to say thank you. I remember being deployed and receiving ‚Äúany soldier‚Äù mail, and the messages from the community were so heartwarming and motivating."  Join us in celebrating our veterans and their invaluable contributions. #VeteransDay #LifeatToyota

Toyota Motor North America has agreed to offtake 100 megawatts (MW) of the electricity generated as part of renewable energy company Savion‚Äôs Martin County Solar Project through a virtual power purchase agreement (VPPA). The project is converting the former Martiki Coal Mine, a brownfield site in Martin County, on the border of Kentucky and West Virginia, into a new solar photovoltaic energy facility. Once an active coal mine on the top of a mountain that closed in the 1990s, the Martiki site has clear access to light from the sun, making it an ideal location for reclamation and the installation of solar photovoltaic panels for electricity generation.   The 100 MW that Toyota will offtake from the project will be used primarily to help reduce the company‚Äôs carbon footprint in North America, supplementing the model it has created of environmental stewardship in Kentucky, the state with Toyota‚Äôs largest vehicle manufacturing plant in the world. The move is in-line with the company‚Äôs plans to make all its operations in North America carbon neutral by 2035.

Fahim was thrilled to return to the 2024 SWARM Hackathon this year, where teams came together to explore, innovate, and inspire. He looked forward to the collaboration, discovery, and creativity that the event fostered.  ‚ÄúThe Hackathon fueled curiosity and discovery‚Äîessential ingredients for innovation,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt allowed us to push boundaries, explore AI-driven solutions, and bring creative ideas to life that impacted the future of our business.‚Äù  Events like the SWARM Hackathon demonstrated the power of innovation through collaboration, inspiring us to shape the future of business with AI-driven solutions. #LifeatToyota #SWARMHackathon

In honor of Hispanic Heritage Month, we are thrilled to celebrate with the theme ‚ÄúAvanzando Juntos: Moving Forward Together‚Äù! This theme emphasizes collaboration, resilience, and the shared journey toward a better future for all, and was created by R&D team member Diego G.! Learn more about Diego and the inspiration behind this year‚Äôs theme and logo.  ‚ÄúThe inspiration behind my logo came from the word ‚Äòtogether‚Äô. I wanted to maintain the essence of the original TODOS logo while incorporating diverse elements of our Hispanic culture that represented a unified front where all cultures come together here at Toyota. Each part of the logo has symbolic meaning: the guitar for our musical heritage, the sun for our indigenous roots, the empanada for culinary diversity, the soccer ball for our passion, and vibrant textiles for Hispanic artistry. The geometric shapes reflect the fast growth and impact of Hispanic culture in this country.  I‚Äôm originally from Santa Cruz, Bolivia, and I spent most of my life in La Paz until 2009, when I moved to South Carolina. During my time in college, I began to appreciate the importance of embracing my culture in America. I take great pride in representing my Bolivian roots as well as my Latino and Hispanic heritage. This commitment has shaped my desire to support others in achieving their goals while also striving to be the best version of myself‚Äîsomeone others can look up to, just as I did when I was starting my career.  Being part of TODOS R&D chapter allows me to reconnect with my roots through our events and interactions with team members. Through TODOS, we always aim to have purposeful events to network, learn and grow as a community. We spend a large amount of our time at work, so being able to bring a sense of ‚ÄúFamilia‚Äù to the workplace is something that I always look for when planning our events.‚Äù  Join us in celebrating the vibrant traditions, rich history, and incredible contributions of the Hispanic community! #HispanicHeritageMonth #LifeAtToyota #StartYourImpossible "

At a very young age, Victoria L. had a deep curiosity for how things worked, and a love for innovation and problem-solving. This fueled her passion to become an engineer! The opportunity to turn ideas into real, impactful results was incredibly motivating for me. Being a woman engineer has given me a unique perspective and a strong sense of purpose. It has driven me to advocate for diversity and inclusion within the workplace and also made me more empathetic and collaborative in my approach to problem-solving.   My experiences have reinforced the importance of perseverance and adaptability in overcoming obstacles and achieving success. To future women in engineering, I would say: never doubt your abilities and always seek out opportunities to learn and grow. Embrace challenges as they come, and don‚Äôt be afraid to advocate for yourself. Remember that diversity is a strength and your unique perspective is invaluable and can drive innovative solutions.  My favorite part about working for Toyota is the company's unwavering commitment to innovation and continuous improvement. The collaborative culture and emphasis on teamwork and respect for people create a supportive and stimulating work environment. I believe that the future of engineering lies in embracing diverse perspectives and fostering an inclusive environment where everyone can thrive. I am committed to mentoring the next generation of engineers and support women in STEM fields."

When it comes to living life, Natalie K. says to find out what makes you feel fulfilled and happy and then pursue it. That‚Äôs one of the reasons why she feels proud to work at Toyota ‚Äî she‚Äôs doing what she loves. Natalie shares more about her #LifeatToyota and what #PrideMonth means to her:   "My favorite thing about working for Toyota is the pride I feel when I see a vehicle I helped design out on the road!  Also, Toyota has greatly supported my identity. Among other things, the support we have for the Spectrum BPG, our benefits, and little things like including preferred pronouns in our online communication tools.    To me Pride Month is about acceptance and, not to be overly simplistic, pride. A lot of people have overcome hardships, stress, and more just for being who they are. It‚Äôs a way to celebrate overcoming those struggles and continuing to move forward, in hopes of inspiring courage in others who may still be struggling. It lets others know they are not alone and that . there are people who accept you, support you, and who love you for exactly who you are.   I joined Spectrum as a member a few years ago because I have a sibling and friends who were members of the LGBTQ+ community. Once I felt comfortable identifying publicly as a member of the LGBTQ+ community, I was graciously welcomed by the Toyota North America Spectrum community. At the end of the day, people are people. Every person has value, and we have more in common than we realize. I‚Äôm hoping my work on the Spectrum board will help at Toyota and beyond."
